head.title: Differential Microbicidal Effects of Bimetallic Iron–Copper Nanoparticles on Escherichia coli and MS2 Coliphage | Environmental Science & Technology

meta.content: Differential Microbicidal Effects of Bimetallic Iron–Copper Nanoparticles on Escherichia coli and MS2 Coliphage

Bimetallic iron–copper nanoparticles (Fe/Cu-NPs) were synthesized by a single-pot surfactant-free method in aqueous solution [via the reduction of ferrous ion to zerovalent iron nanoparticles (Fe-NPs) and the subsequent copper-coating by metal ion exchange]. The produced Fe/Cu-NPs formed aggregates of spherical nanoparticles (approximately 30–70 nm) of Fe–Cu core–shell structures with 11 wt % copper content. The microbicidal effects of Fe/Cu-NPs were explored on Escherichia coli and MS2 coliphage, surrogates for bacterial and viral pathogens, respectively. Fe/Cu-NPs exhibited synergistically enhanced activity for the inactivation of E. coli and MS2, compared to single-metal nanoparticles (i.e., Fe-NPs and Cu-NPs). Various experiments (microbial inactivation tests under different conditions, fluorescence staining assays, experiments using ELISA and qRT-PCR, etc.) suggested that Fe/Cu-NPs inactivate E. coli and MS2 via dual microbicidal mechanisms. Two biocidal copper species [Cu(I) and Cu(III)] can be generated by different redox reactions of Fe/Cu-NPs. It is suggested that E. coli is strongly influenced by the cytotoxicity of Cu(I), while MS2 is inactivated mainly due to the oxidative damages of protein capsid and RNA by Cu(III).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
As nanotechnology rapidly advances, research to apply nanomaterials in environmental engineering is attracting attention.
(1)
Water disinfection using antimicrobial nanoparticles is one of the promising environmental applications of nanotechnology.
(2,3)
For disinfection and microbial control in water, a variety of metal and nonmetal nanoparticles have been studied. In particular, metal nanoparticles in different forms (zerovalent metals, metal oxides, alloys, and composites) containing silver, zinc, magnesium, iron, and copper have been reported to exhibit antimicrobial properties.
(4−9)
The disinfection using nanomaterials has been envisioned as a prospective technology that is free from the production of harmful disinfection byproducts (DBPs) and is advantageous for small-scale point-of-use applications.
(2,3)

Silver-based nanomaterials, mainly silver nanoparticles (Ag-NPs), have been widely studied for microbial control due to the strong antimicrobial activity of silver.
(4,10−12)
The antimicrobial mechanism of Ag-NPs has been explained by the cytotoxicity of released silver ion (which binds to thiol moiety in proteins, causing manifold detrimental effects)
(10,11)
and the disturbance of cell integrity by physicochemical interactions between Ag-NPs and cell components (e.g., affecting the cell membrane permeability).
(12)
Copper is also known as a strong microbicide, and copper-based nanomaterials, including copper and copper oxide nanoparticles, have been tested for their antimicrobial activity.
(4,13−15)
Similar to the case of Ag-NPs, the toxicity of both released copper ion and nanoparticles themselves was suggested to be responsible for the antimicrobial activity of copper nanoparticles (Cu-NPs).

Iron nanoparticles, particularly nanoparticulate zerovalent iron (nZVI or Fe-NPs), have been reported to exhibit antimicrobial properties.
(16−19)
Investigators found that Fe-NPs inactivate
Escherichia coli
and MS2 coliphage mainly by inducing oxidative damage to the cells and viral particles.
(16−19)
Fe-NPs and ferrous ion released from Fe-NPs generate reactive oxidants, such as hydroxyl radical (
•
OH) and ferryl ion [Fe(IV)], via the Fenton(-like) reactions.
(20)
Fe-NPs exhibited microbicidal activity superior to that of silver nanoparticles under anoxic conditions.
(16)
However, the activity of Fe-NPs drastically decreases in the presence of oxygen due to rapid iron corrosion,
(16)
which limits the practical application of Fe-NPs in water disinfection. Meanwhile, a few recent studies have tested iron-based bimetallic nanoparticles for their antimicrobial properties.
(21,22)
They showed that Fe-NPs doped with copper or silver exhibit enhanced antibacterial or antifungal activities.

In this study, we report the synergistically enhanced microbicidal activity of bimetallic iron–copper nanoparticles (Fe/Cu-NPs). Fe/Cu-NPs showed greater inactivation efficacies of
E. coli
and MS2 compared to Fe-NPs and Cu-NPs under both oxic and anoxic conditions. The bactericidal activity of Fe/Cu-NPs for
E. coli
has been tested by a previous study, together with Fe-NPs and three other iron-based bimetallic nanoparticles.
(22)
However, the synergistic microbicidal activity of Fe/Cu-NPs has not yet been clearly addressed. Moreover, little is known about the redox reactions underlying the microbicidal actions of Fe/Cu-NPs (in particular, the reactions involving different valencies of copper species) that are believed to be the key factors in interpreting the microbicidal mechanisms of Fe/Cu-NPs. In addition, this study found that when exposed to Fe/Cu-NPs, the
E. coli
and MS2 coliphage are inactivated by different mechanisms.

The objectives of this study were (i) to evaluate the enhanced microbicidal activity of Fe/Cu-NPs (compared to Fe-NPs and Cu-NPs) and (ii) to elucidate the microbicidal mechanisms in terms of the roles of biocidal agents that are generated by the redox reactions of Fe/Cu-NPs.

div.div:
All chemicals were of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification [refer to
Text S1
of the Supporting Information (SI), for a list of the chemicals used in this study]. All solutions were prepared using deionized water (>18 MΩ·cm, Millipore).

Fe-NPs were synthesized by the aqueous-phase reduction of ferrous ion, in which FeSO
4
and NaBH
4
were used as an iron source and a reducing agent, respectively. Details about the synthetic procedures are described elsewhere.
(16)
In the same manner, Cu-NPs were prepared by the aqueous-phase reduction of cupric ion (using CuSO
4
). Bimetallic nanoparticles (Fe/Cu-NPs) were synthesized by the surface modification of Fe-NPs. The solution of CuSO
4
(6.3 mM, 50 mL) was slowly added into the suspension of Fe-NPs (prepared from 17.9 mM FeSO
4
solution 200 mL) while the suspension stirred vigorously. Nanoparticles were collected by centrifugation. Collected nanoparticles were washed with acetone three times, dried, and stored in a N
2
chamber at room temperature (24 ± 1°C) before use.

The surface morphologies and composition of Fe/Cu-NPs were analyzed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) equipped with energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS) (JEM-2100F, JEOL). The phase and crystalline properties of Fe/Cu-NPs were analyzed by high-power X-ray diffractometry (XRD; D/MAX 2500 V/PC, Rigaku) with Cu Kα radiation. The chemical states of copper and iron were characterized using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; K-alpha, Thermo Fisher). The specific surface area of Fe/Cu-NPs was measured using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method on a Gemini V system (Micromeritics).

E. coli
(ATCC 8739) stock was cultivated in 30 mL of Difco nutrient broth at 37 °C for 18–24 h. The cells were collected by centrifugation at 3000 g for 15 min and washed three times with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS, 10 mM, pH 7.2). The obtained
E. coli
cells were resuspended in 20 mL of PBS and kept in a refrigerator at 4 °C. The spread plate method was employed to determine the population of
E. coli
using nutrient agar.
(23)
The plates were incubated for 18–24 h at 37 °C, and the numbers of colonies were then counted.

MS2 (ATCC 15597-B1) was used with
E. coli
C3000 (ATCC 15597) as a host. The host
E. coli
was cultivated in tryptone broth containing 10 g/L tryptone, 8 g/L NaCl, 1 g/L yeast extract, 1 g/L glucose, 2 mM CaCl
2
, and 0.01 g/L thiamine. MS2 was inoculated in the suspension of host
E. coli
for 18–24 h at 37 °C. Then, the mixture of
E. coli
and MS2 was centrifuged at 3000
g
for 15 min, and the supernatant was filtered with a 0.22 μm PTFE syringe filter. For further purification, the cultured MS2 was filtered by ultrafiltration [20 000 MWCO (molecular weight cutoff) for collecting the filtrate followed by 10 000 MWCO for collecting the retentate].
(24)
The population of MS2 was determined by the plaque assay method using media of the top and bottom double layer containing 0.5% and 1.5% of agar.
(23)

All experiments were performed using 60 mL Pyrex flasks with
E. coli
or MS2 suspensions (10
7
CFU or PFU/mL) at room temperature (24 ± 1°C) and neutral pH (pH 6.8, unbuffered). The inactivation was initiated by adding the microbicidal agent into the microbial suspension under vigorous mixing. A 1 mL aliquot was withdrawn at a predetermined time, immediately mixed with ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), and consecutively diluted with PBS to quench the reaction. Aliquots of samples were assayed on agar plates to count viable cells (or viral particles).

For inactivation experiments under anoxic conditions, the microbial suspension was deaerated by sparging ultrapure N
2
gas. Two millimolar 2,9-dimethyl-1,10-phenanthroline (DMP) and EDTA were used as Cu(I)- and Cu(II)-chelating reagents, respectively, and 10 mM methanol was employed as a scavenger of reactive oxidants {i.e.,
•
OH, cupryl [Cu(III)] species, and Fe(IV)} for some experiments. DMP, EDTA, and methanol were added into the microbial suspension before adding the microbial agent.

Fluorescent probe compounds, hydroxyphenyl fluorescein (HPF) and hydroethidine (HE), were used to analyze the reactive oxidants [i.e., HPF for
•
OH or Cu(III), and HE for superoxide radical anion (O
2
•–
)] generated in the intracellular region.
(25−27)
By the specific reactions with the oxidants, HPF and HE are transformed into strongly fluorescent compounds. To measure intracellular oxidants,
E. coli
cells were stained with the probe compounds;
E. coli
cells were suspended in the probe compound solution (100 μM) while the suspension stirred for 1 h at 100 rpm in the dark. Then, the stained cells were centrifuged and washed three times with PBS and resuspended in the reactor for the treatment by NPs. The treated cells were sampled, and the fluorescence intensity was measured by a microplate reader (Infinite M200, Tecan, Switzerland) at 485 nm excitation and 535 nm emission for HPF and at 535 nm excitation and 590 nm emission for HE. The fluorescence intensity ratio (FIR) relative to the control was presented. More details are described elsewhere.
(18)

div.h3: Analysis of Cell (or Viral Particle) Integrity
div.div:
The LIVE/DEAD
Bac
Light bacterial viability kit (L7012, Molecular Probes, Thermo Fisher) was used to evaluate the cell membrane integrity of
E. coli
. Live and dead cells were stained with SYTO 9 and propidium iodide, respectively; the excitation/emission maxima are 480 nm/500 nm for SYTO 9 and 490 nm/635 nm for propidium iodide. The stained cells (live and dead cells, respectively) were analyzed by confocal laser scanning microscopy (FV1000, Olympus). Standard filter sets, FITC, and Texas Red were used for live and dead cells, and the fluorescence signal was quantified using the IMARIS image processing software (Bitplane).

To analyze the antigenicity loss and the protein oxidation of MS2, the MS2 bacteriophage BioThreat Alert (Tetracore) and OxiSelect Protein Carbonyl (Cell Biolabs) ELISA Kits were used, respectively. The absorbance at 450 nm was measured by microplate reader for quantification. Detailed procedures for these assays are described elsewhere.
(18,19)

The quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) analysis was carried out to quantify the damage to RNA in MS2 treated by NPs. Viral RNA was extracted from the sampled suspensions of MS2 with the QIAamp Viral RNA mini kit (QIAGEN), and the qRT-PCR signals were obtained on a CFX96 real-time system (Bio-Rad). In this study, two RNA sites, which are known to be important for protein maturation and RNA replication, were selected for the analysis. Details of the qRT-PCR analysis are described in the SI (
Text S2
and
Table S1
).

div.h3: Morphology and Surface Properties of Fe/Cu-NPs
div.div:
TEM images show that Fe/Cu-NPs form aggregates of spherical nanoparticles, of which the sizes range from 20 to 70 nm in diameter (
Figure
1
a). Magnified TEM images with EDS analyses show that Fe/Cu-NPs have core–shell structures, in which iron and copper dominate in the inner core and the outer shell, respectively (
Figure
1
, parts b and c). The oxygen content in the outer layers is higher, indicating that zerovalent iron and copper are partially oxidized to their oxide forms (sites B and E); the estimated thickness of oxide layers ranges from 3.3 to 6.1 nm, and these oxide layers can hinder the electron transfer from the core to the surface. In some cases, smaller particulates of zerovalent copper (<10 nm) are deposited on the outer layers (site D). The total contents of iron and copper in Fe/Cu-NPs were measured to be 85 and 11 wt %, respectively (measured by atomic absorption spectroscopy after dissolving Fe/Cu-NPs in HNO
3
). The specific surface area of Fe/Cu-NPs was 35.5 m
2
/g.

div.p: Figure 1. (a–c) HRTEM images and (d) EDS elemental compositions of Fe/Cu-NPs.

div.div:
The XRD spectrum of Fe/Cu-NPs shows a broad peak centered at 2θ = 44.9°, which indicates zerovalent iron (α-Fe) (
Figure S1a
, SI).
(28,29)
XPS spectra identified iron and copper in their oxide forms on the Fe/Cu-NPs surfaces (
Figure S1b
, SI). The peaks at 710.9 and 724.4 eV are assigned to Fe 2p
3/2
and 2p
1/2
of iron oxides, respectively. A shoulder observed at around 706.6 eV is attributed to a Fe 2p
3/2
peak of zerovalent iron.
(29)
The peaks at 932.5 and 952 eV are Cu 2p
3/2
and 2p
1/2
of CuO.
(30)

div.h3:
Inactivation of
E. coli
and MS2 by Fe-, Cu-, and Fe/Cu-NPs
div.div:
The inactivation of
E. coli
and MS2 was examined in the presence of different nanoparticles ([NPs]
0
= 0.05 g/L) under oxic and anoxic conditions (
Figure
2
). Under oxic conditions, Fe/Cu-NPs and Cu-NPs resulted in the
E. coli
inactivation of 4.4 log in 10 min and 3.4 log in 15 min, respectively, whereas Fe-NPs showed negligible bactericidal effect on
E. coli
(
Figure
2
a). Under anoxic conditions, the inactivation efficacies of
E. coli
by Fe/Cu-NPs and Fe-NPs greatly increased (
Figure
2
b); the enhanced bactericidal activity of Fe-NPs under anoxic conditions is consistent with the previous observations.
(16)
Meanwhile, Cu-NPs showed somewhat less inactivation efficacy of
E. coli
under anoxic conditions than under oxic conditions.

div.p:
Figure 2. Inactivation of
E. coli
and MS2 by NPs under oxic and anoxic conditions. Insets indicate the inactivation rates ([Fe-NPs] = [Cu-NPs] = [Fe/Cu-NPs] = 0.05 g/L).

div.div:
Similar to the bactericidal activity, Fe/Cu-NPs also exhibited the greatest virucidal activity toward MS2 under oxic conditions, followed by Cu-NPs and Fe-NPs (
Figure
2
c). Under anoxic conditions, all NPs did not significantly inactivate MS2 (less than 0.7 log inactivation in 15 min,
Figure
2
d).

div.h3: Effects of a Reactive Oxidant Scavenger, Copper-Chelating Agents, and Hydrogen Peroxide
div.div:
To investigate the effects of reactive oxidants and Cu(I) and Cu(II) species on the inactivation of
E. coli
and MS2 by Fe/Cu-NPs, methanol, EDTA, and DMP were employed (
Figures
3
a,b); the average microbial inactivation rates in the absence and presence of reagents are presented. The addition of 10 mM methanol decreased the inactivation rates of
E. coli
and MS2 by 15% and 54%, respectively. Copper-chelating agents significantly inhibited the inactivation of both
E. coli
and MS2. The addition of Cu(I)-chelating agent (DMP) decreased the inactivation rates of
E. coli
and MS2 by 69% and 67%, respectively. The Cu(II)-chelating agent (EDTA) decreased the inactivation rates of
E. coli
and MS2 by more than 90%.

div.p:
Figure 3. Effects of methanol and copper-chelating reagents on the inactivation of (a)
E. coli
and (b) MS2 coliphage by Fe/Cu-NPs. Inactivation rates of (c)
E. coli
and (d) MS2 coliphage by NPs and Cu-NPs with different concentrations of H
2
O
2
. The inset of part c indicates the intracellular oxidant generation ([Fe-NPs] = [Cu-NPs] = [Fe/Cu-NPs] = 0.05 g/L, [MeOH] = 10 mM, and [DMP] = [EDTA] = 2 mM for parts a and b, reaction time = 30 min for parts c and d).

div.div:
Meanwhile, under anoxic conditions, no inhibitory effect of methanol was observed on the
E. coli
inactivation, whereas DMP and EDTA almost eliminated the bactericidal activity of Fe/Cu-NPs (
Figure S2
, SI).

The oxidation of Fe/Cu-NPs under oxic conditions is believed to generate hydrogen peroxide (H
2
O
2
) as an intermediate, which subsequently reacts with copper species to produce reactive oxidants, mainly Cu(III) (refer to the
Discussion
section for details). To test this possibility, the inactivation of
E. coli
and MS2 by Cu-NPs in combination with H
2
O
2
was performed, and the results were compared with the microbial inactivation using Fe/Cu-NPs and Cu-NPs in the absence of H
2
O
2
(
Figure
3
c,d). The addition of H
2
O
2
inhibited the
E. coli
inactivation by Cu-NPs (
Figure
3
c), although it increased the intracellular oxidant levels in
E. coli
cells (the inset of
Figure
3
c; also refer to
Figure S3
, SI).

On the other hand, the addition of H
2
O
2
greatly enhanced the MS2 inactivation by Cu-NPs (
Figure
3
d); increasing the concentration of H
2
O
2
further increased the inactivation rate of MS2.
Figure S4
(SI) shows the kinetic data for the microbial inactivation by Cu-NPs in the presence of H
2
O
2
.

div.h3:
Viability Test of
E. coli
by a Staining Assay
div.div:
A staining assay using the LIVE/DEAD
Bac
Light bacterial viability kit was employed to test the viability of
E. coli
cells during the treatment by different NPs. Inactivated cells (measured by the spread plate method) can be considered as live if their cell membranes are not disrupted.

The live/dead cell ratio decreased with reaction time during the treatment by NPs (
Figure
4
a). Similar to the results of inactivation tests (
Figure
2
a), Fe/Cu-NPs exhibited the greatest bactericidal activity, followed by Cu-NPs and Fe-NPs. To assess the relationship between the cell membrane damage and culturability, the ratios of cell decay measured by the two methods (i.e., the spread plate method and the LIVE/DEAD staining assay) were calculated using the data of
Figures
2
a and
4
a [α = log(
N

N

)
Live/dead
/log(

Inactivation
,

b]. The cells treated by Fe-NPs showed the highest α values, and those treated by Fe/Cu-NPs and Cu-NPs followed.

div.p:
Figure 4. (a)
E. coli
cell decay analyzed by the LIVE/DEAD
Bac
Light staining assay, and (b) calculated α values during the treatment of NPs. Insets of (a) indicate the microscopic images ([Fe-NPs] = [Cu-NPs] = [Fe/Cu-NPs] = 0.05 g/L).

div.h3: Antigenicity, Protein Oxidation, and RNA damage of MS2
div.div:
The reduction of the antigenicity of MS2 was examined during the treatment by NPs (
Figure
5
a). The antigenicity measured by ELISA (expressed by normalized absorbance) decreased with the reaction time. Fe/Cu-NPs resulted in the greatest reduction of antigenicity. Fe-NPs caused greater reduction of antigenicity than Cu-NPs. The oxidation of the protein capsid of MS2 (marked by protein carbonylation) was monitored during the treatment by NPs (
Figure
5
b). The increase in the protein carbonyl groups showed a similar trend to the reduction of antigenicity (i.e., Cu-NPs < Fe-NPs < Fe/Cu-NPs).

div.p:
Figure 5. Variations in the (a) antigenicity, (b) protein carbonyl, and two viral RNA targets [(c) site A and (d) site B; refer to
Table S2
, SI] in MS2 coliphage, during the treatment by NPs ([Fe-NPs] = [Cu-NPs] = [Fe/Cu-NPs] = 0.05 g/L).

div.div:
The qRT-PCR analysis showed that the number of RNA targets in MS2 decreased during the treatment by NPs (
Figures
5
c,d). The RNA damage by NPs increased in the order of Fe-NPs < Cu-NPs < Fe/Cu-NPs.

div.div:
Different microbicidal agents can be generated by the redox reactions of Fe/Cu-NPs in aqueous suspension. Zerovalent iron and copper release ionic iron and copper species, such as Fe(II), Cu(I), and Cu(II), as they are corroded by oxygen (intracellular or extracellular) and cellular components.
Reactions 1
–
4
describe the corrosion process of zerovalent iron and copper by oxygen.
(20,31)
(1)
(2)
(3)
(4)
Among the ionic iron and copper species, Cu(I) is known as a strong microbicide, and it has been suggested to be responsible for the bactericidal actions of different copper-based antimicrobial systems.
(26,27,32)

During the oxidation of Fe/Cu-NPs, microbicidal reactive oxidants are also generated via the Fenton(-like) reactions. H
2
O
2
can be produced by the reactions of oxygen with reduced forms of iron and copper. The two-electron reduction of oxygen by Fe
0
or Cu
0
produces H
2
O
2
(
reactions 1
and
3
). A series of one-electron reductions of oxygen by Fe(II) or Cu(I) also produces H
2
O
2
through the intermediate of O
2
•–
(
reactions 5
–
8
).
(33,34)
(5)
(6)
(7)
(8)
The H
2
O
2
so produced generates reactive oxidants such as Fe(IV), Cu(III), and
•
OH by the Fenton(-like) reactions with Fe(II) and Cu(I) (
reactions 9
and
10
).
(9)
(10)
Previous studies suggested that the iron- and copper-based Fenton(-like) reactions preferentially proceed via a two-electron transfer mechanism at neutral pH to produce Fe(IV) and Cu(III), rather than
•
OH.
(35−38)

Meanwhile, zerovalent iron and copper can donate electrons to recycle Fe(III) and Cu(II) to Fe(II) and Cu(I), which are further used to reduce oxygen and H
2
O
2
.

Under anoxic conditions, no reactive oxidants can be generated in the bulk phase. However, cellular components can lead to the corrosion of Fe
0
and Cu
0
into their ionic species. Due to the reducing environment, most ionic iron and copper species will be present as Fe(II) and Cu(I).

The redox reactions take place primarily on the surface of Fe/Cu-NPs and possibly in the diffuse layer in close proximity to the surface; the concentrations of total dissolved iron and copper released from Fe/Cu-NPs (measured after microfiltration) were 1.16 and <0.1 μM, respectively. When Fe/Cu-NPs contact
E. coli
and MS2, the microbicidal agents generated from Fe/Cu-NPs can be transferred to the cells (or viral particles) through the NP–cell interface. A portion of Fe/Cu-NPs may penetrate into the
E. coli
cells through the disrupted cell membranes, accelerating the transfer of the biocides into the intracellular region. Cu(I), Cu(III), and Fe(IV) (free or surface-bound) are believed to be the potential biocides that may contribute to the microbial inactivation; however, the minor microbicidal activity of Fe-NPs under oxic conditions (
Figure
2
a,c) indicates that the contribution of Fe(IV) is relatively insignificant. The significant inhibition of microbial inactivation in the presence of DMP and EDTA (
Figure
3
a,b) indicates that Cu(I) and Cu(II) species play key roles in the microbicidal actions of Fe/Cu-NPs; Cu(I) is a biocide as well as an intermediate to produce Cu(III), and Cu(II) is the precursor of Cu(I).

The synergistic microbicidal activity of Fe/Cu-NPs is believed to result from the enhanced production of microbicidal copper species [i.e., Cu(I) and Cu(III)] attributed to the reactions of Fe
0
. As a reducing agent, Fe
0
reduces Cu(II) into Cu(I) (
reaction 11
), and Cu(I) is subsequently used to produce Cu(III) through the oxidation process (
reactions 7
,
8
, and
10
).
(11)

This explanation is consistent with our previous observation that a reducing agent (hydroxylamine) accelerates the production of Cu(I) and Cu(III) from Cu(II), enhancing the microbicidal activity of Cu(II).
(27)
In addition, Fe
0
can produce H
2
O
2
by a direct reaction (
reaction 1
) and secondary routes via released Fe(II) (
reactions 5
and
6
); H
2
O
2
is further used to generate Cu(III) (

).

The results obtained in this study collectively show that the inactivation mechanisms of
E. coli
and MS2 by Fe/Cu-NP are different from each other. These differences are mainly explained by the different roles and contributions of Cu(I) and Cu(III); details will be discussed in the following sections.

Cu(I) appears to play a key role in the inactivation of
E. coli
by Fe/Cu-NPs. This explanation is supported by much experimental evidence. First, the enhanced bactericidal activity of Fe/Cu-NPs under anoxic conditions (
Figure
2

reactions 7
,
8
, and
10
).

Second, many observations have not found significant involvement of reactive oxidants, most likely Cu(III), in the
E. coli
inactivation. The effect of methanol (an oxidant scavenger) on the
E. coli
inactivation was minor (
Figure
3
a), indicating that the bactericidal effects of reactive oxidants are not important; the effect of methanol was almost negligible under anoxic conditions, where reactive oxidants are not generated (
Figure S2
, SI). The combined use of Cu-NPs and H
2
O
2
[intended to accelerate the generation of Cu(III)] decreased the inactivation rate of
E. coli
(
Figure
3

2
O
2
[the inset of
Figure
3
c and
Figure S3
(SI)], this increase (31.8–50.8%) is insufficient to cause a substantial inactivation of
E. coli
; the FIR values increased by more than 10-fold in the Cu(II)/H
2
O
2
system.
(26)

Fe/Cu-NPs also exhibited the greatest bactericidal activity in the LIVE/DEAD staining assay of
E. coli
(
Figure
4
a), indicating that during the Fe/Cu-NPs treatment, the cell membranes are significantly disrupted. However, the α values [α = log(
N

/

inactivation
] were the highest when treated by Fe-NPs, followed by Fe/Cu-NPs and then Cu-NPs (
Figure

b). This result implies that the ratios of the membrane-damaged cells to nonculturable cells decreases in the order of Fe-NPs > Fe/Cu-NPs > Cu-NPs. There may be multiple physicochemical effects of NPs to disrupt the cell membranes of
E. coli
, and no simple explanation can apply for the cell membrane disruption. However, it is assumed that the α values are higher when the contribution of reactive oxidants such as Fe(IV) and Cu(III) is high and the contribution of nonoxidizing biocides such as Cu(I) is low. On the basis of the entire results obtained in this study, Cu(I) is believed to be mainly responsible for the
E. coli
inactivation, but other effects (e.g., reactive oxidants or physical interactions between NPs and cells) may disrupt cell membranes to facilitate the penetration of Cu(I) into the intracellular region.

Previous studies have reported that Cu(III) is a strong MS2 virucide.
(26,27)
Cu(III) also appears to play an important role in the inactivation of MS2 by Fe/Cu-NPs. The following observations support this explanation. First, the inactivation rates of MS2 by NPs greatly decreased under anoxic conditions in which reactive oxidants are not generated (
Figure
2
d). Second, methanol significantly inhibited the MS2 inactivation (
Figure
3
b); the residual virucidal activity in the presence of methanol may be attributed to the incomplete scavenging of reactive oxidants by methanol or other biocidal effects of Fe/Cu-NPs [e.g., Cu(I) or physical actions of NPs]. In addition, the combined use of Cu-NPs and H
2
O
2
dramatically enhanced the MS2 inactivation (
Figure
3
d), indicating that H
2
O
2
is a critical reagent to produce Cu(III) from Cu
0
. As described earlier, Fe/Cu-NPs accelerates the in situ generation of H
2
O
2
by different reactions of electron-donating iron species [i.e., Fe
0
and Fe(II)], leading to the greater production of Cu(III), compared to Cu-NPs.

The reduction of antigenicity of MS2 by Fe/Cu-NPs (
Figure
5
a) is believed to result from the damage of the protein capsid, possibly due to the oxidation by Cu(III). This explanation agrees with the increase of protein carbonyl groups by the Fe/Cu-NPs treatment (
Figure
5
b). However, it is noteworthy that Fe-NPs, which showed minor virucidal activity (
Figure
2
c), caused substantial protein oxidation (
Figure
5
a,b), indicating that Fe(IV) effectively oxidizes proteins. On the other hand, the RNA damage by NPs (
Figure
5
c,d) showed a similar trend to the MS2 inactivation (
Figure
2
c). The damage of external capsid may facilitate the attack of biocides on the internal RNA. The lack of RNA damage in the Fe-NPs-treated MS2 indicates that Fe(IV) is not effective in destroying RNA. The greater inactivation of MS2 by Fe/Cu-NPs is thought to result from greater damage of both the protein capsid and RNA induced by Cu(III).

Fe/Cu-NPs can be applied in different areas where water disinfection or antimicrobial action is needed. Fe/Cu-NPs were synthesized by a facile single-batch method that can readily be scaled up for mass production by increasing the batch size. Fe/Cu-NPs exhibited great microbicidal activity toward both bacteria and viruses. The inactivation rates of
E. coli
and MS2 by Fe/Cu-NPs were superior to those of Ag-NPs (
Table S2
, SI), showing its potential as a cost-competitive antimicrobial material. The microbicidal activity of Fe/Cu-NPs did not significantly decrease for at least six months, when stored in a powder form under ambient conditions (data not shown). Fe/Cu-NPs can be applied as both a consumable water disinfectant and an antimicrobial surface-coating material. Depending on their uses, the properties of Fe/Cu-NPs can be further modified (e.g., by controlling the iron and copper content or the degree of surface oxidation); the reactivity and stability of Fe/Cu-NPs are important for the former and latter applications, respectively. Meanwhile, the microbicidal mechanisms of Fe/Cu-NPs suggested in this study [the dual roles of Cu(I) and Cu(III)] provide insight into the design of effective antimicrobial materials and systems using copper species.

A review. The challenge to achieve appropriate disinfection without forming harmful disinfection byproducts by conventional chem. disinfectants, as well as the growing demand for decentralized or point-of-use water treatment and recycling systems calls for new technologies for efficient disinfection and microbial control. Several natural and engineered nanomaterials have demonstrated strong antimicrobial properties through diverse mechanisms including photocatalytic prodn. of reactive oxygen species that damage cell components and viruses (e.g. TiO2, ZnO, and fullerol), compromising the bacterial cell envelope (e.g. peptides, chitosan, carboxyfullerene, carbon nanotubes, ZnO, and silver nanoparticles (nAg)), interruption of energy transduction (e.g. nAg and aq. fullerene nanoparticles (nC60)), and inhibition of enzyme activity and DNA synthesis (e.g. chitosan). Although some nanomaterials were used as antimicrobial agents in consumer products including home purifn. systems as antimicrobial agents, their potential for disinfection or microbial control in system level water treatment was not carefully evaluated. This paper reviews the antimicrobial mechanisms of several nanoparticles, discusses their merits, limitations and applicability for water disinfection and biofouling control, and highlights research needs to utilize novel nanomaterials for water treatment applications.

A review. The challenge to achieve appropriate disinfection without forming harmful disinfection byproducts by conventional chem. disinfectants, as well as the growing demand for decentralized or point-of-use water treatment and recycling systems calls for new technologies for efficient disinfection and microbial control. Several natural and engineered nanomaterials have demonstrated strong antimicrobial properties through diverse mechanisms including photocatalytic prodn. of reactive oxygen species that damage cell components and viruses (e.g. TiO2, ZnO, and fullerol), compromising the bacterial cell envelope (e.g. peptides, chitosan, carboxyfullerene, carbon nanotubes, ZnO, and silver nanoparticles (nAg)), interruption of energy transduction (e.g. nAg and aq. fullerene nanoparticles (nC60)), and inhibition of enzyme activity and DNA synthesis (e.g. chitosan). Although some nanomaterials were used as antimicrobial agents in consumer products including home purifn. systems as antimicrobial agents, their potential for disinfection or microbial control in system level water treatment was not carefully evaluated. This paper reviews the antimicrobial mechanisms of several nanoparticles, discusses their merits, limitations and applicability for water disinfection and biofouling control, and highlights research needs to utilize novel nanomaterials for water treatment applications.

To investigate the mechanism of inhibition of silver ions on microorganisms, two strains of bacteria, namely Gram-neg. Escherichia coli (E. coli) and Gram-pos. Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus), were treated with AgNO3 and studied using combined electron microscopy and X-ray microanal. Similar morphol. changes occurred in both E. coli and S. aureus cells after Ag+ treatment. The cytoplasm membrane detached from the cell wall. A remarkable electron-light region appeared in the center of the cells, which contained condensed DNA mols. There are many small electron-dense granules either surrounding the cell wall or depositing inside the cells. The existence of elements of silver and sulfur in the electron-dense granules and cytoplasm detected by X-ray microanal. suggested the antibacterial mechanism of silver: DNA lost its replication ability and the protein became inactivated after Ag+ treatment. The slighter morphol. changes of S. aureus compared with E. coli recommended a defense system of S. aureus against the inhibitory effects of Ag+ ions.

For nearly a decade, researchers have debated the mechanisms by which AgNPs exert toxicity to bacteria and other organisms. The most elusive question has been whether the AgNPs exert direct "particle-specific" effects beyond the known antimicrobial activity of released silver ions (Ag+). Here, we infer that Ag+ is the definitive mol. toxicant. We rule out direct particle-specific biol. effects by showing the lack of toxicity of AgNPs when synthesized and tested under strictly anaerobic conditions that preclude Ag(0) oxidn. and Ag+ release. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the toxicity of various AgNPs (PEG- or PVP- coated, of three different sizes each) accurately follows the dose-response pattern of E. coli exposed to Ag+ (added as AgNO3). Surprisingly, E. coli survival was stimulated by relatively low (sublethal) concn. of all tested AgNPs and AgNO3 (at 3-8 μg/L Ag+, or 12-31% of the min. lethal concn. Overall, this work suggests that AgNP morphol. properties known to affect antimicrobial activity are indirect effectors that primarily influence Ag+ release. Accordingly, antibacterial activity could be controlled (and environmental impacts could be mitigated) by modulating Ag+ release, possibly through manipulation of oxygen availability, particle size, shape, and/or type of coating.

A review. Endogenously produced pro-oxidant reactive species are essential to life, being involved in several biol. functions. However, when overproduced (e.g. due to exogenous stimulation), or when the levels of antioxidants become severely depleted, these reactive species become highly harmful, causing oxidative stress through the oxidn. of biomols., leading to cellular damage that may become irreversible and cause cell death. The scientific research in the field of reactive oxygen species (ROS) assocd. biol. functions and/or deleterious effects is continuously requiring new sensitive and specific tools in order to enable a deeper insight on its action mechanisms. However, reactive species present some characteristics that make them difficult to detect, namely their very short lifetime and the variety of antioxidants existing in vivo, capable of capturing these reactive species. It is, therefore, essential to develop methodologies capable of overcoming this type of obstacles. Fluorescent probes are excellent sensors of ROS due to their high sensitivity, simplicity in data collection, and high spatial resoln. in microscopic imaging techniques. Hence, the main goal of the present paper is to review the fluorescence methodologies that have been used for detecting ROS in biol. and non-biol. media.
